So when I landed at my layover in Vegas I bought this book to get me through the reIf you read my last , the book I started to read was so bad. So when I landed at my layover in Vegas I bought this book to get me through the rest of the flight to Florida.Never heard of Foley or this book. I don't typically read whodunnits. However, compared to the book that I had to stop reading because the writing was so bad - this was okay.It was a super quick and easy read. The premise was interesting. However, the end got a little silly with twists that just seemed unrealistic. And I noticed a discrepancy in something the main character, "Jess" was doing that didn't make sense in the ending scene. So the story lost some credibility for me based on that, and other "reveals" at the end - that I can't reveal here! All a bit convoluted and ridiculous at the end.I suppose if this is your genre - or if you're a fan of Ms. Foley, you'd enjoy it. For me, it served the purpose of getting me to Florida, then back home to Boise - a distraction from hours of flying! That's about it. ...more

It was so bad that I had to shut the book before we even landed at my layover in Vegas. The dialogue was so poorly written. The man and woman were in their 30s I guess? But sounded like teens. The author, this Lucy Score, wrote in such an awkward, amateurish manner, I seriously couldn't go on. In fact, people may say, "but you didn't even finish". Our principal asked us to read this in a book study. I did it because I needed the credit. Absolutely horrible.All I will say is if you are a new teacher, please, please, do not think that anything in this book is a way to allow students to act. The book is reckless and irresponsible. The author admits she has no evidence or research, that it's all anecdotal. The author looks young and it was hard for me to find out hard details about her like - how long was she actually an elementary teacher? Honestly, she spoke like a true "district person" - having no idea what it really is to teach and to teach to a large group. The teachers in my book study were more worried that our principal would actually think this book had valuable information than concerned about how bad the book was. But we didn't dare speak up - well, only a few brave ones! Hope my principal isn't on Goodreads! ...more

author: Wharton, Edith
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Wharton wrote this when she was 75 and died in 1937. It was published in 1938 in its "unfinished" state. Then someone named Marion Mainwaring "finisheWharton wrote this when she was 75 and died in 1937. It was published in 1938 in its "unfinished" state. Then someone named Marion Mainwaring "finished" it in 1993. Some folks seemed okay with the situation. Other folks like John Updike called it a "bastardization". I guess I fall in the middle somewhere.It wasn't my favorite Wharton book. Too many characters and all that female silliness about debutants, and arranging wealthy marriages in the 1870s-1880s. Americans vs. the Brits, etc. I honestly liked it more as a case study of Edith Wharton herself. It felt very autobiographical since this was the time period where she came of age among the elite in New York society. I liked the education I got on how the royals perceived the Americans at that time, and maybe still today.The beginning dragged a bit and I was never really brought into the drama so it was hard to pick up some days. However, I heard there was a movie and I think a recent TV series made. I'd check it out just for kicks. ...more

title: Washington Square
author: James, Henry
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: I was describing this story to my husband in the middle of reading and he said, "oh, a chick lit story?" Well, hmmm, I don't know if they'd called it I was describing this story to my husband in the middle of reading and he said, "oh, a chick lit story?" Well, hmmm, I don't know if they'd called it "chick lit" in 1880, the year it was published, but I'll say okay.I was expecting so much more. I had heard a lot about Henry James in my college literary classes. And this novel came out 4 years after my favorite author (Mark Twain) published Tom Sawyer and 4 years before Huck Finn. And no, I didn't expect James to be Twain, but I expected him to be GOOD.This was a silly, boring, repetitive tale. The title is based on Washington Square in New York City, but I barely felt the presence of a setting! Some of the characters were well-described physically and through their dialogue, but others I never knew. And the worst part was the second-person narration or what I'm seeing called now: "authorial intrusion". Ugh! I don't know if Henry James used this technique in ALL of his novels, but it was so distracting in this one. Authors, PLEASE don't speak to me while telling the story. Just, please, don't. Once again, I'll end by saying - thank god it was short....more

my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: What happened? I loved Woolf's nonfiction, A Room of One's Own, but this was just awful! So boring! So weirdly frenetic and boring at the same time!ThWhat happened? I loved Woolf's nonfiction, A Room of One's Own, but this was just awful! So boring! So weirdly frenetic and boring at the same time!The whole stream of consciousness set up didn't work for me. And it seems like I keep selecting novels with NO PLOT. I get that this was that post WWI modernist time, 1925, where everyone was depressed and disillusioned, but God, I don't see why this has been considered such an important book! Is it just that it was so "unique" to write about one person's inner thoughts in one day? I was looking for that same wit I loved in her nonfiction (and yes, when I could actually follow some of it, there were moments) but overall, I was not interested in what Mrs. Dalloway was thinking. Bleah!Surely someone has made the connection to Woolf's mental illness and the semi-autobiographical nature of the character, as well, right? Or maybe I'm off there. Too confusing and I don't care....more

title: Lady Chatterley's Lover
author: Lawrence, D.H.
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: I read Lawrence's Sons and Lovers several years ago. I thought Lady Chatterly was a much better and more interesting story. However, I'm still not surI read Lawrence's Sons and Lovers several years ago. I thought Lady Chatterly was a much better and more interesting story. However, I'm still not sure I'm a D.H. Lawrence convert.Yes, this time when they said "obscene", it was - even by modern standards. And that was fine. I just kept wishing it was more of a romantic relationship instead of the Mellors character talking about her "cunt" and "fucking", etc. Eventually, it DID turn into romance, but it took at least the first 100 pages to get there. Maybe more. And again, Lawrence had so much extra detail about the coal miners, the colliers, and all that union vs. management talk. Lots of long speeches by the main male character, "Clifford" and Clifford's friends. Ugh, that part was so boring. Lawrence's father was a coal miner/worker and I guess this lifestyle made a huge imprint on Lawrence. The book was written in 1928, during that whole, weird post WWI time when so many young writers were debating the meaning of life and living and being human. Ugh, too much of these long, philosophical conversations between characters that were really Lawrence positing his own reflections. Again, super boring and unnecessary to the main story. Perhaps I'm being too generous with 4 stars, but I felt like the low GR rating of 3.4 was a little shabby given that this book is so well-known and well-read. And Lawrence, in his short life, really worked hard and wrote like crazy: poems, novellas, short stories, plays, essays, and novels. In both of the novels I've read I found myself continuing to say, "there's something here, I'm just not sure what it is."...more

title: Call Me Crazy: A Memoir
author: Heche, Anne
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: The memoir. Remember - this genre gets a different treatment. So, I'll start with the writing. Amateur hour. It reminded me of my own, unrefined, writThe memoir. Remember - this genre gets a different treatment. So, I'll start with the writing. Amateur hour. It reminded me of my own, unrefined, write-as-you're-speaking text. About 9th grade level. But remember...we're talking memoir here. People who write their memoirs can't write, unless they actually ARE a writer. So what do you expect? I expected basic, and got basic.Now content. It was a campy, Hollywood, movie-star tell-all. With lots of sexual abuse and name dropping. And if you like that kind of thing - this is your book! This was a recommendation, fast read - I read it just over this weekend. Heche drew me in at first, and I was captured by the tales of "forgotten" abuse, living with a closeted gay father and the tragic life this family of six. But then I got a little skeptical toward the end. Especially after reading some of Heche's bio on Wikipedia. I guess others in the family didn't agree with Heche. And even Heche admitted she really did fall off the deep-end in 2000. And now of course, we know of her recent, tragic car accident. Heche was only 53, and after reading her story, it makes me question more about the car accident. All in all, this is your typical memoir. You walk away with more questions than answers. And there are lots of tawdry details that may or may not be true. ...more

review: Pulitzer Prize - 2005. Good Lord I hated this book! And I'm so surprised because I LOVED the book Ms. Robinson wrote about 20 years prior to this callPulitzer Prize - 2005. Good Lord I hated this book! And I'm so surprised because I LOVED the book Ms. Robinson wrote about 20 years prior to this called Housekeeping. What the hell?Folks, I need stories, okay? Maybe I'm irritated because I've run into this for several books lately, but I want a plot. Sorry if that's asking too much. So I guess that's the main reason this didn't work for me.Also, my own problem here, but I'm not keen on the epistolary novel strategy. I always say I need my fiction to be real, and when it's delivered in letter form, it feels even faker than fiction. This was so contrived. As one of my GR friends said about this book, "writing just to hear yourself write". I don't know - there are so many people these days spouting off, pontificating, and instructing others how to live, I just couldn't handle it. Moments of Henry David Thoreau started coming back to me and pissing me off. I still have PTSD from Walden Pond. Marilyn Robinson is soon to be 80. She's from northern Idaho. I know my silly  here won't hurt her phenomenal success, as she's laughing all the way to the bank. And I think she's a great writer, as many people do. But this book? Bleah! ...more

title: Elizabeth Alone
author: Trevor, William
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: I'm struggling between 3 and 4 stars here, but I love William Trevor, so I'm rounding up.This is the third book I've read of Trevor's. I did not enjoyI'm struggling between 3 and 4 stars here, but I love William Trevor, so I'm rounding up.This is the third book I've read of Trevor's. I did not enjoy it as much as Children of Dynmouth and Miss Gomez and the Brethren. However, it still had all the of hallmarks of Trevor's unbelievable ability to capture people's personalities. In fact, the book felt like more of a character study. I didn't even realize that there was a "main" character. And when I started counting I got up to 20 characters - and every one was distinct, unique, and authentic. William Trevor was a people watcher - for sure! So many great scenes of random people. Here's one of my favorite parts - just a brief encounter with a dissatisfied customer of Henry's piece-of-shit vending machines:"In a fury he banged the side of the defective machine with his fist, shouting that he had a dog's life, claiming the country hadn't been governed properly since the War." Hilarious! And we all know this person, don't we?And Trevor is equally skilled at portraying women and men and children. There was even a dog who could have walked off the pages!All that being said, the novel lacked a bit of plotline which made me a little bored with it at times. If you need a strong plot with lots of problems/solutions, rising/falling, as well as changing scenes, etc. This may not be for you. This was one of these more getting-into-people's-heads stories. If you like that - pick it up - hopefully, there are some old copies hanging around out there! ...more

title: The Bell Jar
author: Plath, Sylvia
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Wow, not sure where to go with this. First, I'm embarrassed to say I didn't know much about Sylvia Plath. I guess I shouldn't be embarrassed because tWow, not sure where to go with this. First, I'm embarrassed to say I didn't know much about Sylvia Plath. I guess I shouldn't be embarrassed because this WAS her ONLY novel. Apparently she's better known for her poems and I'm eager to read them now. For some reason I had Plath lumped with that Gertrude Stein group! And I thought she was English! I knew she had killed herself, but I thought she was older. Didn't realize she was 29 while writing the novel, and was dead by 30. So I did a bit of research before I started.Then once I started reading Bell Jar, it was obvious that Plath was from that group of writers - born in the 1930s, coming of age in the conformist, conservative 1950s. J.D. Salinger was older, but Plath's tone fits in with Catcher in the Rye for sure. Ken Kesey's Cuckoo's Nest comes to mind as well.I'm struggling to  this - so I'm going to fall back on the old pro/con list method. PROs: The writing was strong. Excellent metaphors and similes. One liners that could blow your socks off. You could tell Plath was a poet at heart. Also, it was short and easy to read. Very quick read. Another thing I liked is that it oozed that whole late 50's, early 60's feeling. Plath's language was contemporary and cool and modern for the time. CONs: The book was published in January of 1963 in England. Plath killed herself in February of 1963 in her apartment with her two young kids (she taped their bedroom door and put towels up to block the gas from the oven, but still!) So I couldn't help thinking of her writing this while she must have been in a depressed or bipolar state. Also, it's labeled a work of fiction. It's not. And her husband, Ted Hughes, and her mother were so aware of that that they wouldn't publish it in the states until 1971. Why does this matter? Because as a work of fiction, it falls flat. Little character development, no real climax, problem/solution, settings were a little weak, etc. However, as a memoir it was an excellent depiction of how people who suffer from depression really feel. On top of that, given the time period where even wearing a "different" color or not having the right landscaping could brand you as a lunatic, Plath captured that constrictive nature of the time. So perhaps I need to put that in the PRO section! There were times that I felt like I was reading something too personal and it made me uncomfortable. Is that a PRO or CON? I hope this book is not in high schools. The suicidal ideation is just too much. Page after page. Well, at least when she returns from New York. In fact, that abrupt shift sort of threw me, too. I rather liked the first part and just labelled it: Normal 1950s Teenage Angst. But then it took a pretty dark turn. So...DON'T read it if you suffer from depression. DO read it if you know someone who suffers from depression and you want more insight. ...more

I did not like it as much as I thought I would.If you're unfamiliar, these books feature 20 short stories. They are chosen by the "guest" editor for the year. And that guest editor writes an interesting essay at the beginning of the book saying how, why, where, when he/she made the selections. I always find that part pretty interesting.So for the 1990 book, guest editor was Richard Ford. I think what I learned is that Mr. Ford and I don't have similar tastes in short stories. I'd say I only really enjoyed 5 of the stories:Alice Munro, "Differently"Alice Munro, "Wigtime"Joy Williams, "The Little Winter"Joan Wickersham, "Commuter Marriage"Christopher Tilghman, "In A Father's Place" Not to say there weren't solid writers in the collection, but the stories just didn't appeal to me.However, now I will look for other short stories, novels, essays by the authors I mentioned above. ...more

review: Aww, this was a sweet, little, romantic comedy - perfect for a summer poolside/beach read. I loved it and finished it quickly.It's hard to write a romAww, this was a sweet, little, romantic comedy - perfect for a summer poolside/beach read. I loved it and finished it quickly.It's hard to write a romance that isn't cheesy, but Ms. Wolitzer accomplishes just that. And I loved that the main characters were in their 60's and 50's and still vibrant and interested in participating in life with friends and lovers. I cringed a bit when I saw the low GR average rating (3.5). My guess is that readers didn't find it "meaty" enough? Correct, it is not Steinbeck or Hemingway. It also has a tidy little happy ending for all the characters. Some readers don't like tidy. But Wolitzer's writing is solid and engaging. I was hooked after the first page. Another huge bonus was Wolitzer's treatment of all the women characters. They were all over 50, but Wolitzer described all of them in flattering ways and made them sound like goddesses! Yes! ...more

title: George Washington's Secret Six: The Spy Ring That Saved the American Revolution
author: Kilmeade, Brian
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: I was wavering between a 3 and 4 - not because the content, but because of the writing style."The Spy Ring" is an important story in the tale of the AI was wavering between a 3 and 4 - not because the content, but because of the writing style."The Spy Ring" is an important story in the tale of the American Revolution. In 2016, when I visited Manhattan, people asked about if we were going to any shows or sporting events. I said, "nope - we're touring this whole island and learning about George Washington!" I think most Americans forget that so much of the war was in New York. I think Americans also forget how outmanned and outskilled our ragtag army was compared to the British. So - clever General Washington realized, um, yea, I'm going to have to re-think how we are going to fight this thing! Enter this book. Well-researched information on how Washington used spies to pull off some major battles and fake "set-ups" and beat the British at their own game. Fascinating. And even relevant today and to how espionage is an important, but often overlooked piece to warfare.My only negative on this is the writing. It was very basic. In some ways it felt like it was written for a young adult audience. Also, the authors chose to include "fictional dialogue". Ugh, thank god there wasn't too much of this, but I absolutely hated it. It felt forced, contrived, and too melodramatic. Completely unnecessary. Otherwise it's a must-read. And coming in at under 230 pages - refreshing! ...more

title: The Life of Elizabeth I
author: Weir, Alison
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Oh my gosh! This has taken me almost a month to finish! Comes in at right under 500 pages - about 200 pages too long. I wanted to go with 3 stars, butOh my gosh! This has taken me almost a month to finish! Comes in at right under 500 pages - about 200 pages too long. I wanted to go with 3 stars, but I'll be generous and give Ms. Weir 4 stars for all the research she had to do!This book was published over 20 years ago. I guess since then, Ms. Weir has become quite the expert on English monarchies. What I liked about the book was obviously, learning more about Elizabeth I. I visited England in the 1980's and learned a lot about Elizabeth's father - even visited Hampton Court. This book cleared up several historical questions I had had through the years. Especially with regard to Mary Queen of Scots.What I did not like is that I felt very repetitive - particularly in the first 150 pages. It just kept going over and over again about Elizabeth not being married, needing to marry, and different permutations of that idea. I felt it got old, and it made me wonder if Weir became too single-focused on that rather than other government issues that were taking place at the beginning of Elizabeth's reign. OR was it not Weir's fault? Perhaps she couldn't find as much information about the early years? However, this finally started to get better and other topics were addressed. So that's probably why I ended up with the higher rating. I also felt like in certain parts Weir sort of assumed that her readers were English - or let's say already had a strong background in English history. I guess that's okay. I'm sure American authors do that with our own historical books. But I had to do a lot of research on my own to get up to speed.This is one of those "not for everyone" reads. But I do recommend it - especially if you have time to a long story!...more

I have to say this, to me, was a novel that showed true growth in Gaines from a "writer" to a "novelist". The pieces that make one care in a novel were not present in "House", but were palpable in "Dying". On top of all that, excellent portrayal of race in America. ...more

title: The Feminine Mystique
author: Friedan, Betty
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Oh boy. I thought this was going to be much better than it was. I've just been reading some s - good and bad. I don't want to be all over the plOh boy. I thought this was going to be much better than it was. I've just been reading some s - good and bad. I don't want to be all over the place like Friedan was in this self-indulgent, 500 page manifesto - so I'll lay it out positives/negatives.PROS: So great that this book brought attention to the issues of women! I'm also glad it led Friedan to create N.O.W. Some of the negative s said it was too dated. Yes, it's a nonfiction piece from 1963, it's going to be dated, people. That's not my gripe at all. I liked reading it in "real-time" for her writing it and realizing how discriminatory it still was for women at that time on almost every level. I'm watching the fiction series "Mrs. Maisel" on Amazon right now and it's the same period and the producers are doing a great job portraying what a "man's world" it really was. In fact, the first 200 pages held my interest. Friedan created chapters that were more like mini-essays and I particularly liked the one chapter where she stopped talking about her own opinions, and shared some history of the women's movement with pioneers like Elizabeth Cady Stanton, etc.CONS: Oh my, my. Where do I start? I guess first on how we define "science". I have scientists in my family: a geologist, dentist, and ecologist. Then there's the "social sciences". Can we all admit those are a little loosey-goosey? To top it off, then we have Ms. Friedan. Got her Bachelor's in psychology. That's it. Wrote articles for women's magazines. Said she wanted her PhD, but a "boyfriend made me quit". Um, okay. One would be hard-pressed to find one shred of real evidence or facts to back up all of her theories. However, I'm not even necessarily coming down on her for this - except she presented everything as if she had made some huge, factual, scientific discovery. From what I could tell, Friedan's book was based on anecdotes. And worse? Based on her OWN frustrating life. Now I'm getting to the point: this should have been sold/billed/published as a MEMOIR. All of us can pontificate and spout off any time we want - free country. But there was such an arrogance here that just seeped through the pages and became unbearable by the end. And in a nutshell her total theory is: no woman is a real, fulfilled woman unless she has a career. Kids should be few, and raised by the government (yes, she said her mother and mothers of her generation "smothered" their children by being there for them). If a woman enjoys cooking or sewing or makeup (I like 2 out of those 3!) she has been lied to and is now lying about liking it! Friedan is rude to homosexuals, said they made her uncomfortable and didn't include them in her "depressed housewife" analysis. To say nothing of black/brown women, or white women who didn't go to school. Friedan was Jewish, so I couldn't even believe when she started comparing housewives to people who suffered in concentration camps. She contradicts herself in several chapters - seemingly annoyed with the heavy emphasis on Freudian thought in the 40's and 50's, but then supporting his other theories later on the in book? Maybe Friedan was just a product of her time and place, as we all are. She was born in 1921, my grandmother's generation. She basically said she was completely unhappy being married and having kids. And I can see that in that generation, that would have been frustrating because a woman was expected to do just that. I just wish she could have been more objective and more inclusive and less judgmental and narrow-focused. ...more

title: Night        (The Night Trilogy, #1)
author: Wiesel, Elie

review: Please read this story. Yes, the content is devastating. But it is short, and oh so important and poignant!First reason to read: it falls into the warPlease read this story. Yes, the content is devastating. But it is short, and oh so important and poignant!First reason to read: it falls into the war-is-hell category. If we don't know our history, we're destined to repeat it - as someone once said, right? Wiesel did an incredible job here of saying - know your history, count your blessings, and don't ever take peace for granted. Message received, Mr. Wiesel.Second reason to read: This part was a huge takeaway for me. Wiesel started the story with himself as a young teen in Sighet in Romania in 1944. Obviously, his parents were following news updates about the war, the Germans, etc. But Wiesel was masterful at showing how easily his whole town was sort of smoothly scooped up into this drama, leaving their homes forever. When just nights before they thought they were not going to be part of this drama! Oh how quickly everything got BAD. Fast! This made me think of myself and my own home. I'm embarrassed at how apathetic I've become to current events, world news, and involvement in the process. Most recently (January!), remember the crazy Chinese spy balloon that flew over our whole country? I sort of just dismissed it when I saw that our OWN president Biden and government didn't seem too alarmed. Why was I so willing to ignore it? I guess I'd say I'm too busy at my own job as a teacher, I'm distracted, I'm disgusted with Biden and Trump - two useless presidents in a row. But Wiesel's story has given me pause. These little incidents can add up quickly. That's how it happened to Wiesel's family. I think for me, personally, I always have this attitude of "let's not ruffle feathers, let's not upset other countries, let's not make more of it than it needs to be." But at the end of the book, Wiesel's Nobel speech was included and he spoke about that very thing - almost getting too comfortable and not questioning and then not taking action to prevent governments from atrocities. I think I need to get my head in the game a little more so that I don't have any "surprise" visitors (fill in the country of your choice here) telling ME to leave. And I need to vote for politicians who will protect me better than I would possibly be able to protect myself! ...more

title: That Old Ace in the Hole
author: Proulx, Annie
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Ugh. This has been exhausting. I was the only human that didn't care for Shipping News. This was even worse. Except it at least had punctuation and prUgh. This has been exhausting. I was the only human that didn't care for Shipping News. This was even worse. Except it at least had punctuation and pronouns! - I can't remember now, but Shipping News was missing either punctuation or pronouns. Which made it cumbersome and frustrating to read.Well, this one was cumbersome and frustrating, too. First, Proulx does the weird name thing again. OMG! I can't stand it. Main character: Bob Dollar. There's a Rope Butt, Hugh Dough. You may think - why is this woman so annoyed? But the names felt contrived and silly and weirdly made up so that would bring me out of the story. And just like Shipping News, there were SO MANY characters and with the odd names, I couldn't remember who was who. Second, and worse still - so much focus on the landscape - again, like Shipping News. This time instead of the ocean it was the Texas panhandle, and fields and cows in just too much detail. And not enough forward-moving plot to get me through that landscape.Third, and the worst part of all - Proulx did that thing where the main action is happening with the main character, Bob Dollar. Then Bob will be talking to LaVon and LaVon will say, "oh yea, I remember old cranky Ace Crouch" and from there, the LaVon character is telling a LONGGGGG backstory on whoever this Ace Crouch is. Literally for pages and pages. Some of you may say, oh, that's fun to hear the backgrounds! But it's background of characters who have no part in the active storyline and don't even re-enter later in the story. It's kind of like how nobody really wants to hear about what someone dreamed about last night! It's meaningless chatter that I started to skim through. If the writing is incredible, then at least you might enjoy the long tale. But Proulx's writing feels like a forced folksy-tone and over-the-top shenanigans that are supposed to be humorous but are more schmaltzy and corny than anything else.All that being said, her descriptions of that area seem spot on. I've been in locales like that and she is accurate in her portrayal of the landscape, the barns, the houses, the sounds. Proulx describes characters as they're talking - and she's very detailed with their farting, spitting, snorting - which I'm saying is a positive and trying to throw her a bone here. Because frankly, I'm done with Proulx now. Y'all can have her. ...more

title: Shrub: The Short but Happy Political Life of George W. Bush
author: Ivins, Molly
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: I come from a weird perspective on this one. I loved Molly Ivins AND I loved George Bush. How can that be?I loved how sarcastic and acerbic Ivins was I come from a weird perspective on this one. I loved Molly Ivins AND I loved George Bush. How can that be?I loved how sarcastic and acerbic Ivins was - whether in print or when I used to see her on the morning political pundit shows. I loved how she called a spade a spade and didn't give a shit who heard. I loved how she somehow balanced her liberal views with her conservative roots in Texas. Ivins battled an alcohol addiction her whole life, but I also love that she still worked her ass off every day. I loved George Bush for the opposite reasons. He was not funny or sarcastic. He was kind and caring. He also battled addiction in his early days, but was able to find the power to overcome. Bush DID give a shit who heard him, and it was difficult for him to put his thoughts into words. But he was a quiet, sentimental, and unassuming man. He often reminded me of my father with his quick-to-cry manner. And as Ivins said, truly was a friend to all and knew almost every man and women in the Texas statehouse - and their families. And cared.These two were long-time love/hate sparring partners. So keep that in mind as Ivins outlines his life in politics BEFORE being president. Ivins does a fine job of offering up different topics per chapter and the book is a quick, easy read. Obviously, she's quite critical, as she should be. But as I tell my students, it's also hard to get the whole story from "data". Especially if it's POLITICAL. There were many subjects she mentioned that I could see how both sides would view the evidence differently. Another thing to consider: as with all politicians, time and history are important. Ivins wrote this book 23 years ago, and before Bush's presidency, 9/11, and his "post-presidency life". I was lucky to meet Bush when he visited here in Boise during his second campaign. Briefly spoke to him and my takeaway was respectful and genuine. I'm proud of Molly Ivins, too, as even though she disagreed with most of Bush's policies, she frequently mentioned some of his best qualities. When she died from terrible breast cancer, Bush was one of the first people to offer public condolence and kind words about her. To me, this is how the politican/reporter relationship should look. ...more

title: Brave New World
author: Huxley, Aldous
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: I struggled between 3 and 4 with this one. I'm still on the fence.There's no doubt that the futuristic world that Huxley presents here is actually whaI struggled between 3 and 4 with this one. I'm still on the fence.There's no doubt that the futuristic world that Huxley presents here is actually what and how we're pretty much living today. Frozen embryos, happy pills, no one really having deep conversations for fear of hurting someone's feelings or disrupting their ignorant bliss. So for people that like dystopian fiction and want to make those connections - you'll get it here.However, it also felt terribly dated. From the outset the Director is leading a group around the facility and he refers to them as, "fellows". I immediately thought why wouldn't there be women? Oh yea, this was written in 1932, no women in the workforce. Then Huxley says the fellows were "quickly scribbling their notes on their legal pads" so that just felt dated, too. The whole thing reminded me of an old 1930s black and white "science fiction" picture on the TCM channel. Not to mention lots of typical 1930s racist attitudes and calling folks negros and octoroons. Awkward. Oh, and super awkward - at the beginning Huxley kept talking about hundreds of young naked boys and girls engaged in erotic play. Um, ew. I understand all the sex that Huxley had the adults engaged in. Since "free sex" wasn't around in 1932 and Huxley was trying to show this future way of thinking that adults could have sex whenever and wherever they like. And that was fine. But the sexuality of kids, I don't know, made me wonder about Huxley...just sayin'. On the other hand, I was impressed with Huxley's writing and his resume. I had no idea how prolific he was - plays, essays, poems, fiction, non-fiction. The end of the story offered wisdom and philosophies (during Mond's discussion with Hemholtz, Savage, and Bernard) and words to live by. I would read another Huxley story for sure. But for Ford's sake, no more sci-fi. ...more

title: The Lost Daughters of China: Abandoned Girls, Their Journey to America, and the Search for a Missing Past
author: Evans, Karin
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: This is a must-read for anyone who has adopted from China or daughters who were adopted from China and are young adult women now. So much of Mrs. EvanThis is a must-read for anyone who has adopted from China or daughters who were adopted from China and are young adult women now. So much of Mrs. Evans's experience reminded me of my sister's experience. I think the best thing that Evans does in this book is not only discuss all the "lost daughters", but all the "lost mothers". Because of China's one-child policy (and/or variations of it) as of 1980, all of these poor women who had to give away (the author doesn't like the word abandon, and I agree) their daughters is unreal! In a country where the author says abortion is easy, prevalent and encouraged - it says so much that some women chose to actually go through the birth process, and maybe even tried to keep/hide her daughter and then a husband, boyfriend, or parent told the woman to leave her daughter somewhere and "hopefully" the daughter would be discovered - how unbelievably sad. The scant studies that had been done before this book showed that it was overwhelmingly a family member - not the mother - that said they would have to leave the daughter somewhere else and hope someone caring and able would find her. I guess I had never thought about the birth mother and the absolute pain she went through. I sort of labeled her as "the bad guy" in this story. I'm so sorry I thought that way. Mrs. Evans' does a good job of weaving in her own story of the process of paperwork and excitement at adding a little girl into their family with the global and political whys and hows of this whole movement of Chinese daughters.The only downfall of this book is it was written in 2000 - so much has happened since. The daughters from the 1990s are in their 20s & 30s now. What is their perspective on all of this? The birth mothers are most likely alive too, if they didn't commit suicide (the author says that China has the highest rates of suicide among women!). Another issue is now there's a shortage of women in China. Young men are finding it difficult to even find someone to start a life with. Lots of unanswered questions. A very balanced portrayal....more

title: Empty Mansions: The Mysterious Life of Huguette Clark and the Spending of a Great American Fortune
author: Dedman, Bill*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Ha! I just spent a few minutes reading the interesting variety of GR s on this. Originally, I thought I'd be rating it a 4 - mainly because I knHa! I just spent a few minutes reading the interesting variety of GR s on this. Originally, I thought I'd be rating it a 4 - mainly because I know the amount of extensive research Dedman had to do on this thing. But truly, it's a solid 3 stars. Here's why:PROS: GR ers were pretty split - they either liked the first part and hated the second, or vice versa! I actually liked the first half better. This part focused on the father, W.A. Clark 1839-1925. I found it interesting that he ranks up there with the Gilded Age Robber Barons like Carnegie and Rockefeller and I'd never heard of him. Clark amassed a FORTUNE from mining copper in Montana and then moved to Manhattan. But the story is about his DAUGHTER, Huguette. She never earned anything or even became anything. And was a strange recluse with no husband, no kids, and not much of a life.CONS: Dedman is a good writer. Easy to read. Yet I had this nagging feeling that he was holding back on criticizing or judging how Huguette lived. I read other ers say this was to Dedman's credit - but there was a dishonesty about it. I think it's because his co-author was Huguette's cousin, and Dedman didn't want to offend the cousin? I'm not sure. Then every once in a while, Dedman made it sound like Huguette was strange, but didn't explore it. Also, I didn't read any s that mentioned this point, but I thought Dedman was going to delve into this woman's condition. Obviously, she had some kind of autism or phobia. Maybe he just couldn't find evidence on that? It was like he refused to paint Huguette in a bad light. In the end, I guess I'm not sure why the author wrote it or what he wants me to feel here. Is the theme supposed to be "it's okay to be quirky"? Is it "one can do what one wants with one's own money"? There was a bit of People-magazine-feeling to it because Huguette was definitely weirdly "fascinating". But I felt like Dedman was manipulating me to think, well, what a sweet, old, rich lady. Instead, I'm actually kind of sickened by her life. All of that money going to waste in mansions she never lived in, Monets and Renoirs she barely looked at, doll collections she didn't touch, jewels she never wore, etc. It's bad enough her father was from that generation that didn't care that they DECIMATED the land and poisoned the rivers, but then Huguette did nothing really to rectify this. She did give money away, but to a few friends and to people who served her - nurses, accountants, doctors, managers. Oh and art museums. After her death it was mainly to taxes and lawyers. She could have done so much good. Dedman kept saying how tender and sweet and kind she was, but only to about six people in her whole life. I guess Dedman is leaving it up to the reader. I say her 104 years of being incredibly wealthy were squandered and I don't know that that's enough for a book. ...more

title: Ploughshares        (Winter 2004-2005)
author: Harjo, Joy*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Ploughshares is a journal out of Emerson College in Boston. This particular volume had 6 short stories and over 20 poems. I found it in the free-littlPloughshares is a journal out of Emerson College in Boston. This particular volume had 6 short stories and over 20 poems. I read many of the poems in here and hated every one. Sorry. I just can't stand all the gibberish. It sounds like random words they pulled out of their asses and placed them erratically on the page and called it a "poem". Guest editor Joy Harjo tried to "warn" me in her intro to be open to what poetry is now. Can't do it, Joy. I'll stick with Robert Frost. However, 3 stars for the EXCELLENT short stories. One I loved was called "The Princess of Nebraska" by Yiyun Li. I'm going to seek her out now and check out more of her short story collections and novels. ...more

title: Chester Alan Arthur        (The American Presidents, #21)
author: Karabell, Zachary
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Do all presidential biographies have to be massive, 800-page tomes? No!This book was such a refreshing surprise. You may be thinking, well, it's aboutDo all presidential biographies have to be massive, 800-page tomes? No!This book was such a refreshing surprise. You may be thinking, well, it's about a president no one remembers, so of course, it's going to be short! But that's not how it felt. Zachary Karabell covered Arthur's presidency in great detail. Yet it was easy-to-read, engaging, and even humorous at times. And under 200 pages! This Gilded Age time period in America - after the Civil War, but before the 20th century - has always intrigued me. I read Destiny of the Republic years ago about poor Garfield's short presidency and then his ordeal of being shot and living for several months before infection finally did him in. Well, I had forgotten that "Chet" Arthur had been his vice president. So this sort of "picked up" where Millard left off. Karabell also does a nice job of painting a balanced portrayal of President Arthur. I loved it!!...more

title: Of Mice and Men
author: Steinbeck, John
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Okay, so really, what am I going to write here that hasn't already been said? Written in 1937, a slim novella ringing in at 107 pages and classic SteiOkay, so really, what am I going to write here that hasn't already been said? Written in 1937, a slim novella ringing in at 107 pages and classic Steinbeck. The only author I know who can capture the entire human condition in one paragraph (sometimes one sentence). It sounds so cliché, but Steinbeck had that rare ability to set an entire mood and scene with very few words. I want to touch on something, though, that I read in some other GR s. The one female character: "Curley's wife" - no name. Yes, as a woman, it's hard to see how the character is portrayed. She's awful. But I think we're doing Steinbeck and the story a disservice if we decide there's a "flaw" because of how she is portrayed. I think we see this reluctance to create a minority character who's wicked more and more nowadays - whether it's a woman, a person of color, a member of the LGBTQ community - aren't there evil folks in EACH of those categories, too? Of course there are! If a character is offensive, do they not belong in the story? And any woman who is reading this, can't you agree that Steinbeck "portrayed" a woman we have all known at least once in our lives? Now, I guess you could say, okay, yes, there are woman like that, but I don't want to read about them. Ok, that's fine. But please don't say that they SHOULDN'T be portrayed that way. Steinbeck NAILED that character. On top of that, if you read closely, you'll see that Steinbeck is not completely one-sided with her, either. In the scene where she's talking to Crooks, Candy, and Lennie, you can hear the utter sadness and disappointment. Steinbeck rounds out her evil with longing, fear, vulnerability, and confusion. So I think it's hard to say that Steinbeck is "portraying" her badly or falsely. Especially considering it's 1937. Talk about trapped! No wonder she's such a bitch! I was going to end this by saying everyone should read this book and everyone should read Steinbeck. I'll stand by that, but - "reader beware" - Steinbeck is REAL. And reality ain't for everyone. 10 Stars for reality and impeccable writing!...more

title: Chasing the Last Laugh: Mark Twain's Raucous and Redemptive Round-the-World Comedy Tour
author: Zacks, Richard
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Richard Zacks may be my new favorite nonfiction writer!My sister gave me this book about 4 years ago. I'm sorry it has been on my "to-read" list for sRichard Zacks may be my new favorite nonfiction writer!My sister gave me this book about 4 years ago. I'm sorry it has been on my "to-read" list for so long. It takes a lot for me to give 5 stars. I'll try to stay brief - but here's why!First, I give Zacks a lot of credit. I've read a ton about Twain. There's been a ton written about Twain. What can anyone say that is new or fresh? Well, I loved that Zacks zeroed in on a very specific time period - toward the end of Twain's life - 1894-early 1900s. Twain died in 1910. I enjoyed the focus and details about Twain's world speaking tour with his wife and middle daughter. Secondly, Zacks wrote it in a comfortable, conversational tone that made 400 pages just whiz by. I didn't want it to end. Zacks included lots of excerpts from Twain's letters. Some of the best letters were to his good friend, billionaire H.H. Rogers in New York. And I thought it was balanced between Twain's actual words, biographical info from Zacks, and then the words of those close to Twain.If I had to think of why someone would not like it, I suppose it might be the numbers and dollar amounts that Twain was making at each "comedy" show, and what he owed his creditors. But really, I'm not a numbers person, and not interested in finances, and I didn't think it was overbearing or boring.Twain was one of those rare humans who comes along once in a lifetime - unforgettable....more

title: In My Father's House
author: Gaines, Ernest J.
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: This read very much like a play. Almost all dialogue and really only four settings: Virginia's boarding house (this was only for a short time), PhilliThis read very much like a play. Almost all dialogue and really only four settings: Virginia's boarding house (this was only for a short time), Phillip's home, Phillip's car, and Chippo's house at the end. PROS: Dialogue was well written. Totally authentic, easy-to-understand. I also thought the ending was great. I read ers say it felt unfinished, but I thought it stayed true to the story and was good to not have it tied up in a neat little bow. Felt real.CONS: I will mirror what I read many ers say - the biggest problem - REPETITIVE. First, it was repetitive in physical descriptions. Everyone was either dark brown, light brown. But what was worse was the repetition in the INTERNAL DIALOGUE (I think that's what it's called). Without giving anything away, one of the beginning scenes Phillip is asking himself the SAME questions OVER AND OVER AND OVER. I love reflection, but reflection that might be moving the story forward, or if not that, allowing me to learn about the character. On top of that, there was too much internal dialogue. Who is that man? I know that man. Who is that man? Why do I know that man? Why isn't this relationship working? Was it working? Is this relationship working? Why isn't this working? Oh. My. God. I was begging the author to get out of this mental vortex and get to the next scene. The characters were flat. The only character who felt developed was Chippo - and he only entered the last few pages of the story! I never knew who was who. And females were nonexistent except his wife, and she was barely there. I thought at first, well, it's the 70's. Nah. That's not gonna work. In the 1930's Steinbeck created Kate Trask; in the 1940s James Cain gave us Mildred Pierce, etc. etc. Some important females may have helped this story. Frankly, I felt a bit duped. I thought that there was going to be a big reveal toward the end as to what some terrible incident was. But as it turns out, the terrible incident was already hashed out in one of the many "internal dialogue" scenes. There was no additional "terrible". I'll still read another book by Gaines, but this one was a disappointment....more

I hated the selections so much - the poetry in particular was just awful and everything was angry, trying to hard to be trendy, or victim-themed. I didn't even bother to  it here on GR. And I'll never pick it up again if that's the direction the editor wants to take it. Then this little gem comes along to renew my faith in university journals! Balanced variety of fiction to nonfiction, poetry, folios, and essays. Some of my favorites: the short stories by Sarah Ann Strickley, Preeta Samarasan, the nonfiction by Shena McAuliffe, the essay by Rebecca Lehmann, and poet William Brown's "Ode to My Hernia". ...more

title: Seinfeldia: How a Show About Nothing Changed Everything
author: Armstrong, Jennifer Keishin*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Ha! This may be one of those times where I had the bar set so low that the only way to go was up! I thought this was going to be cheesy and lame. MaybHa! This may be one of those times where I had the bar set so low that the only way to go was up! I thought this was going to be cheesy and lame. Maybe because of the cover? But I can't believe that I actually enjoyed it!The writing is nothing special at all. Felt like an average magazine article. Also, if you're not a true, die hard fan of Seinfeld, don't even bother. But I loved all the old references and reading about how Larry David and Jerry Seinfeld created it, how they changed the way sitcoms were done, and all the inside stories about the various writers throughout the years. It made me feel good and brought back lots of memories. I actually remember the airing of the pilot in 1989! I wasn't even married yet, and I was at my boyfriend's house. When the episode ended, we just kind of looked at each other like - meh. And yet.... and yet... later that evening we both said - there's something different here. The show was like no other comedy that we had seen. And the rest was history. I watched every episode for the next 9 years. During the show's run I moved from Florida to Idaho, got married, switched jobs 3 times, but my constant was always Thursday night on NBC! Those half hours were sacred. And now, of course, I've seen the series over and over in syndication. In fact, my husband and I were just on a road trip watching TV in the motel room and we caught it on three different channels!One of the points the authors makes is that very few people have ever been as committed to a show since Seinfeld. That's me. I've enjoyed other sitcoms - probably "The Office" comes close, but nothing like Seinfeld. Ms. Armstrong also wrote at first that the executives kept saying "too Jewish", "too New York", but that never affected its popularity. I agree. But I did notice when I moved to the west that not as many people that I'd talk to watched the show or thought it was as hilarious as I did. I grew up in south Florida where I was friends with many people who were Jewish and from New York. I KNEW these characters! Lastly, I had to laugh when the author mentioned that fans have a tendency to be able to draw a parallel from their own lives to any or every scene from the show - but they have to be careful because it becomes annoying quickly. Ha! If my sister, Julie, is reading this, she will recognize the two of us in that statement!I guess the fact we're talking about a show and quoting scenes 24 years after its ending says it all....more

title: The Henna Artist        (The Jaipur Trilogy, #1)
author: Joshi, Alka*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: I think I can easily say a solid 3-star on this one. No better, no worse. It was a lightening fast, non-challenging, poolside, airplane, or in my caseI think I can easily say a solid 3-star on this one. No better, no worse. It was a lightening fast, non-challenging, poolside, airplane, or in my case road-trip read. Pros: from the first page the plot hooks you in. Lots of colorful characters who, for the most part are pretty well-developed. Some history about India and castes in the 1950s. However, not knowing much about India and specifically, Jaipur, I have no idea how authentic the history was.Cons: plot was over-the-top dramatic. Very soap opera. Very predictable - I knew what was coming quite early on. Non-believable events at every turn. A very poor village outcast child is familiar with English authors like the Bronte sisters? The main character's henna cures everything from skin rashes to sex drive? And many more silly occurrences so the author could make it all come together with an unrealistic, happy Hollywood - or Baliwood - ending! Ha! Even with the "cons", I always wanted to pick it up and see what was happening to these Indian ladies, kids, and men! Namaste!...more
